<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0606/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 156, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 78, 615, 97]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 139, 576, 159]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 171, 255, 190]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 201, 400, 221]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 220, 596, 255]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 278, 243, 297]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 297, 767, 339]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 351, 514, 390]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 415, 400, 435]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 440, 551, 472]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 351, 514]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = ar^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 515, 445, 551]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 553, 432, 584]]<|/det|>
\[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 617, 611, 637]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 650, 173, 668]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 678, 598, 732]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 772, 256, 791]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 800, 608, 836]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 833, 610, 855]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 861, 571, 890]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 581, 94]]<|/det|>
Variables \(x\) and \(y\) are related by the equation \(y = x\sqrt{1 + 2x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 100, 230, 121]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 275, 146, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
It is given that when \(y = 12\), \(x = 4\). Find the approximate change in \(x\) when \(y\) increases from 12 by the small amount 0.06.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 291, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 144, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 539, 729, 560]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the stationary point on the curve \(y = x\sqrt{1 + 2x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 537, 920, 556]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 71, 586, 89]]<|/det|>
**DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS QUESTION.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 816, 123]]<|/det|>
The polynomial p is defined by \(\mathrm{p}(x) = ax^{3} - 3x^{2} - 3x + b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 143, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 757, 152]]<|/det|>
Given that \(x = 2\) and \(x = -1\) are roots of the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\), find \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 504, 146, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 384, 523]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 598, 92]]<|/det|>
Use a graphical method to solve the inequality \(|2x - 8| > 4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 103, 915, 755]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 586, 88]]<|/det|>
**DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS QUESTION.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 102, 747, 121]]<|/det|>
Write \((5 - \sqrt{3})(\sqrt{6} + \sqrt{2})^{-2}\) in the form \(a + b\sqrt{3}\) , where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 71, 479, 88]]<|/det|>
A class of 10 students includes Abby and Ben.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
A group of 5 students is to be selected from the class. Find the number of possible groups in the following cases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 390, 168]]<|/det|>
There are no restrictions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 257, 180, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 256, 507, 275]]<|/det|>
The group includes both Abby and Ben.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 257, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 412, 180, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 412, 608, 431]]<|/det|>
The group includes either Abby or Ben, but not both.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 412, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 567, 144, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 566, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
All 10 students are arranged in a line. How many arrangements are possible if there are exactly three students between Abby and Ben?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 581, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 468, 88]]<|/det|>
In this question time is measured in seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
A particle is moving in a straight line with constant velocity of \(6\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) . At time \(t = 0\) , it passes a fixed point \(A\). At time \(t = 5\) it suddenly changes direction and moves with a different constant velocity along the same straight line. It passes the point \(A\) again at time \(t = 15\). Sketch the velocity–time graph for the motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 178, 705, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 146, 561]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 542, 920, 591]]<|/det|>
Another particle is moving in a straight line with constant acceleration. At time \(t = 0\) it passes a fixed point \(B\) with velocity \(-8 \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) . It passes the point \(B\) again at time \(t = 20\) . Sketch the velocity–time graph for the motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 574, 920, 591]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 603, 720, 845]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = x - \frac{x^2}{4}\) and the line \(y = -4\). The curve and the line intersect at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 126, 715, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 146, 434]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 833, 434]]<|/det|>
The maximum point on the curve is at a perpendicular distance \(h\) from the line \(y = -4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 431, 311, 448]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 415, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 144, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 774, 305]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between the tangent to the curve at \(A\) and the line \(y = -4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 288, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 102, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
In this question \(\mathbf{i}\) is a unit vector in the positive \(x\)-direction and \(\mathbf{j}\) is a unit vector in the positive \(y\)-direction. Time is in seconds and distances are in metres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 116, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the initial positions and velocities of two particles, \(A\) and \(B\), that move in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 163, 715, 381]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
Particle \(A\) starts from the origin \(O\) at time \(t = 0\). It moves with constant speed \(10 \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) in the direction \(60^{\circ}\) above the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 144, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 447, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
Find the exact values of the components of the velocity of particle \(A\) in the \(x\)-direction and the \(y\)-direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 464, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 680, 146, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 680, 626, 700]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(t\), the position vector of particle \(A\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 920, 114]]<|/det|>
Particle \(B\) starts from the point \((2\sqrt{3}, 9)\) at time \(t = 0\). It moves with constant speed \(\frac{5}{3} \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) parallel to the positive \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 127, 143, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 126, 628, 144]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(t\), the position vector of particle \(B\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 146, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 450, 470]]<|/det|>
Hence show that the particles collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 451, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A metal tank is in the shape of a cuboid with a square base of side \(x \text{m}\) and an open top. The tank has a volume of \(5 \text{m}^3\). Given that \(x\) can vary, and that the area of the metal used to make the tank is a minimum, find the dimensions of the tank.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
